Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Post-seismic response updip of the Chilean megathrust earthquake of February 27, 2010
Award.AbstractNarration: Among the hazards that arise from large earthquakes are the direct effects of great earthquakes, as evidenced by last year?s devastating earthquake off Japan, and local and distant effects of tsunamis. Though they pose enormous risks to life and property in highly populated areas, neither of these phenomena is as yet well understood. The recent great earthquake in Chile did not generate a large tsunami, probably because the rupture produce a surface break at the seafloor. Available evidence suggests that slip did not occur at depths shallower than about 30 km down-dip from the trench. Accordingly, the proponents of this project infer that the outer accretionary wedge that lies along the Chile coast above the rupture zone behaves as a poro-elastic medium that will adjust over time to the new stress regime caused by the earthquake. The aim of the proposal is to observe the effects of this transient adjustment, by deploying a focused array of ocean bottom seismographs equipped with flow meters. The principal broader impact of this effort is considerably improved understanding of megathrust earthquakes and tsunamis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to use combined seismometer data and fluid flow data (a proxy for volumetric strain) to investigate how the outer accretionary prism offshore Chile recovers from the 2010 Maule megthrust earthquake. Fluid flow meters were attached to NSF supplied ocean bottom seismometers (OBS) for this purpose. The OBSs failed to function properly with only 3 of the 10 recording useful data, and that was mostly of poor quality. The flow meters functioned and recorded flow but because the OBS facility did not allow the use of heavy anchors on the instruments, the OBSs slowly settled into the sediment for most of the recording period, masking any meaningful flow. This technique had worked previously for us using different OBSs and heavy anchors which solidly embedded the instrument into the sea floor. That technique resulted in excellent results, one PhD thesis and multiple peer reviewed publications. This project was a complete failure with regards to its goal. My co-PI did collect some high quality seismic profiles across the region that has proven useful. The primary reason for the failure was that we did not get the OBSs that we had asked for, and the ones supplied were a last minute rush job by the OBS facility that not only were insufficiently tested, they weren't even completely assembled until done so on the ship just prior to deployment.
